title: Nine holds onto NRL free-to-air television rights
text:
Nine will broadcast four games per week on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings and Sunday afternoons. It has also held into the final series, the State of Origin and any other special rugby league matches. Photo: Getty Images
Nine Entertainment has retained the free-to-air broadcast rights to the National Rugby League as well as acquiring free streaming rights to the four games it will air from 2018 through to 2022 in a deal worth $185 million per year.
Nine will broadcast four games per week on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings and Sunday afternoons. It has also held into the final series, the State of Origin and any other special rugby league matches.
However, the NRL has the option of grant pay simulcast rights for certain games.
In the previous rights deal Nine had broadcast rights to three games per week, and three Thursday evening games each year.
Advertisement It was thought the NRL would look to in split the regular competition and State of Origin in order to leverage the amount of money it could get from the rights.
The cost of the rights is inclusive of contra which will be reduced if the NRL elects to grant pay simulcast rights for certain games.
Nine chief executive David Gyngell said that rugby league is a part of the broadcaster's DNA.
"This is a transformational outcome for supporters, Rugby League and Nine, enabling viewers to see the best of the NRL, live and free, 4 days per week, anywhere, on any device," Mr Gyngell said.
"As the audience for television fragments, the value and marketing power of free, live premium sport across multiple media cannot be underestimated."
